commentary.line: Tomorrow is the day - the day when India take on Pakistan in a mouth-watering, saliva-dripping, goose-bump inducing clash at the Adelaide Oval. We'll be there very early for the game. I'm not sure whether I will sleep tonight. Maybe I will, for today's game will force me to take a good rest. So enough for now then. Do join us for that big clash. Until then, it's Srivathsa and Akshay who are signing off from here. It's been a long day, so remember to sleep tight when you can! Adios Amigos!

So that's that then. We've had a superb opening game of the World Cup. It was such a pleasure bringing you the coverage for this game. We've had a ball. Hope you liked it and loved it. The World Cup has just begun and Australia are doing battle with England at the 'G'. Hop tabs to follow all the action. Thanks for all the comments as well. It kept us going.
@holdingwilley: "Kulasekara, the 2nd bowler to start proceedings in a World cup after bowling the last over in the previous one. First was McDermott"
@sidvee: "Boult bowling yorkers as easily as Indian bowlers bowl long hops"
@statanalyst: "@BLACKCAPS' record in @cricketworldcup openers: Played - 11 tournaments, Won - 9 of their opening matches, Lost - 2 (1983 & 2003)"

Here are a few tweets related to the game. Some crackers in here. First up is @cricketaakash with this tweet: "NZ has beaten SL for the first time in the last six World Cup meetings...favourites played like one. Bossed the game."
Before we wind up our coverage here are a couple of user comments

Brendon McCullum: "Yeah, really good performance and when you have such a long wait for this game to finally unfold. You always hope the performances you had leading into will always stack up and today we just continued to play some good cricket and executed our blueprint with the bat. If anything I thought it might swing and that is why we were looking to bowl first if we had won the toss. It was purely overhead conditions, it was an outstanding cricket wicket which had good pace and carry, probably little bit on the slower side. We were able to lay a foundation to then see some of our bigger hitters come in towards the end. Even 330 on the board at half time you are still a bit nervous. Considering how many world class players Sri Lankans have got. We look forward to the next game now. It's great to beat a tough Sri Lankan team. Really pleasing on our ability to use cross seamers today and take the ball off down the fourth and fifth stump line was a deliberate ploy and they used the short ball on this wicket as well. Trent Boult and Adam Milne were touch expensive at the start and the way they came back searching for wickets was the key. This is what we were able to do with those guys. Tim Southee led us again and Daniel Vettori was brilliant as always. A really thorough performance from us. Well certainly he is the closest we have got (on a question asked on Twitter regarding the comparison between Milne and Shane Bond). I think he has a little bit of Bondy's action (Shane Bond) as well. And they both bowled very fast. He is a great weapon to have amongst our team. I can probably confirm that the tweet is probably correct."

Angelo Mathews: "Not really. We knew it was a going to be a good wicket, so we had to bowl pretty well. The bowlers started off very poorly and the bowlers bowled well in the middle part, towards the end we once again didn't bowl pretty well and it was backed up by poor fielding. Especially after the start that they got, they were 100/0 in the 13th over, we did pretty well to pull them back, but I thought we gave 30-40 runs too many. Fortunately while batting we got off to a good start, but once again we lost our way in the middle. Absolutely, when you are chasing 300 plus, you need someone in the top four to try and get a biggie and backed up by good batting in the middle order. Unfortunately, we didn't do it. We are not going to panic, we still have five more games to go and we will keep our heads high and try to win. Of course he (Malinga) will get better and better we all know what kind of a bowler he is and he will come back strong."

Anderson: "It's nice to come back home and play in front of family and friends and I guess a World Cup opener at home is what kids dream of. To do it at Christchurch, at home is a really good feeling. Yeah, there was more nerves than normal, but you play your normal game and you always want to do well for New Zealand. It just happens to be a World Cup and it's a bit more riding on it. I always had a different plan when I tend to walk out to bat. It was nice to build a few partnerships with Grant (Elliott) and Ronchs (Ronchi) and come in and turn that par total into a winning total. It's always nice to start off the World Cup campaign on it. Brendon (McCullum) held me back a little bit for the end and during the powerplay. It was nice to have a little bit of a role. Our other bowlers did an unbelievable job. Dan (Vettori) bowled really well and took them out of the game pretty early. It was a credit to all the bowlers and they took a couple of poles each as well."
Corey Anderson is the Man of the Match

Earlier in the day, New Zealand batsmen weathered the overcast conditions and saw off the new ball. Brendon McCullum played a blinder at the start and Guptill supported him ably. Fifties from Williamson and Anderson saw the Black Caps post a massive total on the board. Once they scored over 300, the match was almost theirs as they have never lost at home after scoring 300. Do stay with us for a few more minutes as we bring you the presentation...

New Zealand bowlers were exceptional. Boult struggled with the new ball, but came back strongly with the old one. Vettori used his experience to outfox the batsmen and he was well supported by the rest of his mates. Southee was the pick of the bowlers, he got the new cherry to swing and picked up his two wickets at the fag end of the innings. Milne bowled with a lot of pace and troubled the batsmen with it. The fielding as usual was top notch from the hosts.

The only other batsman who showed some sort of application was the Sri Lankan skipper Mathews. He fell four short of his fifty and tried to manufacture a shot as he kept running out of partners. Mahela too didn't trouble the scorers as Vettori snapped him for a duck. The over-reliance on Dilshan, Sangakkara and Mahela was clearly seen in this game, as they fell apart when two of them failed.

The first match of the 2015 World Cup has just finished and as most expected it is New Zealand who have come out on top. The players shake hands and walk off to a standing ovation from their supporters. Sri Lanka started well as the opening pair put on a fifty plus stand. Thirimanne looked in excellent touch as he brought up his 11th ODI fifty. Dilshan struggled before Vettori sent him packing. Sangakkara came out and didn't seem to be in any sort of trouble before Boult came back to nip out both Thiri and Sanga.

46.1   Corey Anderson to Herath, out Caught by Milne!! New Zealand thrash Sri Lanka! The first game of the tournament ends and it's the co-hosts who have come out on top. The slower delivery does the trick for Corey Anderson, Herath early into the drive and spoons a catch to cover. Milne accepts the dolly. Herath c Milne b Corey Anderson 13(19) [4s-2]
Corey Anderson to Herath, THATS OUT!! Caught!!
46.1   Corey Anderson to Herath, wide, another short ball and again wide called for height
Corey Anderson [3.0-0-17-1] is back into the attack
45.6   Southee to Lakmal, no run, Southee looks for the yorker, but bowls it outside off, Lakmal drives and misses
Now round the wicket is Southee for the final delivery
45.5   Southee to Herath, 1 run, Herath looks to punch that through the off-side, the ball dribbles off the thick inside half to deep mid-wicket
45.5   Southee to Herath, wide, the short ball has been called a wide for height. Herath this time ducked under it. The square leg umpire called it
45.4   Southee to Lakmal, 1 run, pitched up outside off, Lakmal scythes that to sweeper cover, after shuffling across a little
45.3   Southee to Lakmal, 2 runs, short on the stumps, Lakmal makes room and pulls it away to deep mid-wicket, for a couple
45.2   Southee to Lakmal, no run, nips back in and Lakmal is half-forward while driving, gets an inside edge that dribbles to mid-on
45.1   Southee to Lakmal, no run, short of length on off, dabbed to point
Herath wanted to duck under that short delivery, but took his eyes off it and was late in doing so. Milne patted Herath on the back after checking on him
44.6   Milne to Herath, 2 runs, Herath gets inside the line and deflects it to fine leg, for a couple
44.5   Milne to Herath, no run, Milne comes round the wicket, delivers a yorker length delivery outside off, squeezed out to point

44.4   Milne to Herath, no run, wow! Milne has hit Herath on the helmet! Good to see Milne walk up to Herath and ask him whether he is fine, the batsman nods and all the Kiwis are now checking on him. The helmet is off and he takes a breather. Pacy short delivery, didn't get up, Herath expected it to bounce more and head-butted it to point. That pinged him flush on the badge of the helmet. Herath is a brave man. But great to see the sportsmanship on show
44.3   Milne to Lakmal, 1 run, the inswinging yorker, follows Lakmal as he made room, dug out through mid-wicket, single taken
44.2   Milne to Lakmal, no run, pitched up outside off, driven to short cover
44.1   Milne to Lakmal, no run, Milne to Lakmal and it's the same old story again, play and a miss outside off

Here's what Jamie had to say about the streaker who interrupted play at the Hagley Oval - "It took six security guards to bring down a portly, probably pretty drunk male streaker. The crowd loved it."
43.6   Southee to Herath, no run, quick sharp bouncer, has Herath ducking for cover, he was down in a hurry as the ball flew to Ronchi
43.5   Southee to Herath, no run, pulled straight to the fielder at backward square leg, there is a direct hit at Lakmal's end, but Lakmal was in all the time
43.4   Southee to Herath, no run, Herath defends and gets an inside edge onto the pads, the ball rolls to the right of Southee, Lakmal wanted the single, but Herath wasn't even remotely interested
43.3   Southee to Herath, FOUR, Herath can bat! Width on offer outside off, Herath carves a square cut between point and cover. No-one sweeping on the off-side and it's a boundary
43.2   Southee to Lakmal, 1 run, short of length outside off, guided with an open face wide of the diving backward point, single to third man
43.1   Southee to Lakmal, no run, Lakmal keeps trying his luck outside off and he keeps getting away, short and wide outside off, now a cut and a miss

42.6   Milne to Lakmal, 1 run, cue for wild celebrations! Lakmal has just got bat off a Milne delivery in the over after five beatens in a row. Drives wide of mid-off and takes the single on offer, retains the strike with that run
42.5   Milne to Lakmal, no run, this is incredible! Five! Same ball, same shot, same result
42.4   Milne to Lakmal, no run, 4 now! Lakmal wants to go out in glory, only that Milne isn't bowling on the stumps, do I need to say more here?
42.3   Milne to Lakmal, no run, make that three beatens in a row. Lakmal is just swinging wildly as Milne bowls full and outside off
42.2   Milne to Lakmal, no run, pitched up outside off, Lakmal goes for a big drive and misses
Looking at the replays of the Malinga dismissal, he almost guided it off the face of the bat. Not sure what he was trying, looking to guide it towards third man when there was a slip placed
42.1   Milne to Lakmal, no run, nips back in and Lakmal's iffy poke from the crease meets thin air as the ball rushes past the outside edge
Adam Milne [8.0-0-52-2] is back into the attack
41.6   Southee to Lakmal, 1 run, nips back in and catches the inside edge, it runs to mid-wicket and they take a single
Suranga Lakmal, right handed bat, comes to the crease

41.5   Southee to Malinga, out Caught by Ronchi!! Malinga is out for a golden duck. Good pacy back of a length delivery outside off, Malinga was backing away and fended out, an easy catch as the outside edge is found. NZ one wicket away from a win. Malinga c Ronchi b Southee 0(1)
Southee to Malinga, THATS OUT!! Caught!!

41.4   Southee to Herath, 1 run, turns it to the left of Southee, the bowler runs to field and can't stop it cleanly, the batsmen look at each other and then decide to take the single after a bit of hesitation
41.3   Southee to Herath, no run, driven straight to the fielder at cover
Lasith Malinga, right handed bat, comes to the crease
Baz and Southee have a chat about the field placements. Southee will go round the wicket to Herath now

41.2   Southee to Mathews, out Caught by Vettori!! End of Mathews and probably end of Sri Lanka as well. You can safely say that it's almost over for Sri Lanka. Hang on! Are they checking for the back foot no-ball? Yes they are and Southee is fine. His heel was in the air and didn't land, cutting the side crease. Mathews charged Southee and top-edged the pull, as the ball got big on him, Vettori ran in from mid-on and took a good running catch. Mathews c Vettori b Southee 46(52) [4s-5]
Southee to Mathews, THATS OUT!! Caught!!
Mathews wants to do this on his own. But it will need a miracle from him to pull this off
41.1   Southee to Mathews, no run, Mathews makes room and tucks it to deep backward square, doesn't take the single
40.6   Corey Anderson to Herath, no run, completely mistimed by Herath as Corey Anderson fields in his followthrough
40.5   Corey Anderson to Herath, no run, that is a well-directed short delivery, Herath was beaten for pace as he pulled and missed
40.4   Corey Anderson to Herath, FOUR, that is a nice stroke. A tad overpitched outside off, Herath opens the face of the bat and drives over the leaping point, connected well and gets a boundary
40.4   Corey Anderson to Herath, wide, the slower delivery goes wrong, way outside off, Herath cuts and misses
40.3   Corey Anderson to Herath, no run, gets forward and drives sweetly, but picks out mid-off
40.3   Corey Anderson to Herath, wide, that is a wide for sure. Very short delivery, no chance for Herath to lay any bat. Easy call for the umpire
40.2   Corey Anderson to Herath, no run, it was close to a wide as it was dug in short down leg, Herath got inside the line to pull and missed. Not called though
40.1   Corey Anderson to Mathews, 1 run, slower delivery outside off, Mathews gets forward and drives to long-off

Jamie on Sri Lanka's summer in New Zealand - “Heading into the final ten overs, Sri Lanka’s required rate is already past 12. New Zealand looking at two points with time to spare, unless Mathews can produce something special. It’s really all come down to how poorly Sri Lanka batted in these conditions. There were runs on offer but they couldn’t hold it together. Not a new trend for them on tour in New Zealand.”
39.6   Southee to Mathews, 1 run, full on the stumps, Mathews keeps strike with a single to long-on
39.6   Southee to Mathews, wide, slower short ball, down leg, called a wide after Mathews tried to pull and missed
39.5   Southee to Herath, 1 run, dug in short and Herath swivels on the pull to send it to deep mid-wicket, timed it well, but hit it straight to the fielder
39.4   Southee to Herath, no run, a little noise as the ball went past bat on the drive, lovely delivery in the corridor of uncertainty, drawing the drive and beating the batsman
39.3   Southee to Mathews, 1 run, comes down the track and drives to mid-off, the fielder slides to his left to field and keeps it to a single
39.2   Southee to Mathews, no run, slower delivery on the stumps, Mathews makes room for the big hit, has to defend and does so

39.1   Southee to Mathews, FOUR, that is a top shot! Backs away and slashes it to deep backward point, the ball was bouncing but Mathews got on top of the bounce. Knew the fielders were inside the ring and executed it beautifully
38.6   Corey Anderson to Herath, no run, short of length outside off, defended to short cover
38.5   Corey Anderson to Mathews, 1 run, gets forward and eases a drive through point, easy single

38.4   Corey Anderson to Mathews, FOUR, cut to the left of Kane at point, he dives over the ball and can't run back to prevent the boundary. He tried to get after the ball, but it beat him. Should've been saved that
38.3   Corey Anderson to Mathews, no run, tucked straight to the fielder at backward square leg
Rangana Herath, left handed bat, comes to the crease

38.2   Corey Anderson to N Kulasekara, out Caught by Elliott!! Anderson's fine match continues. After some runs with the bat, he picks up his first wicket. Kulasekara charges down, makes room and looks to free his arms, Anderson bowls it wide outside off, Kula reaches out and slices it in the air towards sweeper cover, Elliott runs forward, settles under it and takes a low catch. New Zealand inch closer towards victory. N Kulasekara c Elliott b Corey Anderson 10(21) [4s-1]
Corey Anderson to N Kulasekara, THATS OUT!! Caught!!
38.1   Corey Anderson to Mathews, 1 run, pitched up from outside off, Mathews mistimes the drive to long-off
37.6   Southee to Mathews, 1 run, angled in on the pads, Mathews glances it towards short fine leg

37.5   Southee to Mathews, FOUR, this time he connects with the pull, short delivery from Southee, Mathews got into position quickly and pulls it in the air over square leg, the ball bounced only a couple of times before reaching the fence

37.4   Southee to Mathews, 2 runs, another teaser for McCullum. It just about clears him. He shakes his head as he retrieves the ball. Southee sees Mathews give the charge and drops it short, Mathews ends up splicing it in the air just over mid-off, Baz leapt up but it was too high, he gives chase and hauls the ball in before the rope
37.3   Southee to N Kulasekara, 1 run, again, the length is short, Kulasekara hangs back and wrists it to mid-on
37.2   Southee to N Kulasekara, no run, back of a length and just outside off, Kulasekara punches and finds backward point
37.1   Southee to N Kulasekara, no run, shortish and outside off, Kulasekara flashes a cuts and fails to make contact

Jamie on the wily old fox, Daniel Vettori - "How crucial were Vettori's ten overs? All the talk has been about pace but he proved how valuable he still can be. Two huge wickets and hardly any runs on offer. Used the surface excellently."
Tim Southee [5.0-1-15-0] is back into the attack
The batting powerplay yielded 19 runs for the loss of no wickets

36.6   Corey Anderson to Mathews, no run, run-out chance missed! Mathews was a goner had he not dived. He tucks it to backward square, is halfway down the pitch before Kulasekara sends him back. Taylor throws the ball to the keeper instead of going for the direct hit, Mathews just about made it with the dive
36.5   Corey Anderson to N Kulasekara, 1 run, goes for a mighty heave towards cow corner, gets it off the inside part to mid-wicket

36.4   Corey Anderson to N Kulasekara, no run, dropped! Taylor puts down a sitter. This was a regulation catch. Short of a length and around off, Kulasekara looks to force it off the back foot, the ball flies to the left of Taylor, who is standing at a wide slip position. He gets both hands and parries it to Ronchi, he gets a glove but can't react fast enough to hold on
A slip is in place..
36.3   Corey Anderson to Mathews, 1 run, angled in on the hips, Mathews tucks it to backward square leg, to the right of Taylor
36.2   Corey Anderson to N Kulasekara, 1 run, shortens the length just outside off, Kulasekara stands tall and punches it to sweeper cover
36.1   Corey Anderson to Mathews, 1 run, starts from round the wicket, Mathews bunts it between point and cover for a single
Corey Anderson, left-arm fast medium, comes into the attack
35.6   Milne to Mathews, 1 run, gives Milne the charge, converts it into a low full toss and drives it to mid-off, Baz was sitting right on the edge of the circle
35.5   Milne to Mathews, no run, Mathews backs away to the leg-side, Milne follows him with a fast full toss, driven back to the bowler

35.4   Milne to N Kulasekara, 1 run, back of a length and holds its line, Kulasekara is squared up as he goes back to defend, the ball takes the outside edge and runs down to third man, Southee tidies up in the deep
35.3   Milne to N Kulasekara, no run, bouncer close to off, Kulasekara sinks down and allows it to sail over
35.2   Milne to Mathews, 1 run, Milne follows Mathews with an yorker, the batsman squeezes it out to mid-on. That hurried onto him
35.1   Milne to Mathews, no run, lifter around off, Mathews gets underneath it and lets it pass
35.1   Milne to Mathews, wide, sprays it down leg, Mathews gets inside the line and shoulders arms, easy call for the ump

Vettori finishes his spell and what a way to start his World Cup campaign! He ends with 2/34 in his 10 overs. The two wickets were of Dilshan and Mahela. In fact the batting powerplay had been taken two overs back. Apologies for not notifying about it..
34.6   Vettori to N Kulasekara, no run, fires it into the blockhole, Kulasekara digs it out to mid-on
34.5   Vettori to N Kulasekara, no run, flatter and on off, Kulasekara mistimes the punch in front of cover
34.5   Vettori to N Kulasekara, wide, slips one down leg, Kulasekara can't lay bat on that, wided signalled
34.4   Vettori to N Kulasekara, no run, drags the length back, turned away gently to backward square leg, straight to the fielder
34.3   Vettori to Mathews, 1 run, flighted on off, Mathews eases the drive to long-off
34.2   Vettori to Mathews, no run, quicker and just outside off, Mathews misses out on the cut shot, he was outdone for pace on that occasion
34.1   Vettori to Mathews, no run, slower and around off, Mathews defends it to short cover

Time for some drinks. New Zealand are well on course to register a win in the first game of the tournament. The only thing between them and the win will be Mathews' wicket. Can the Sri Lanka skipper pull off a miraculous victory? We'll soon find out.

33.6   Milne to N Kulasekara, FOUR, fabulous shot! It was overpitched on off and middle, Kulasekara presents the full face of the bat and drives it beautifully straight down the ground. No chance for either mid-on or mid-off to stop that
33.5   Milne to N Kulasekara, no run, change of pace outside off, Kulasekara has nothing to do with it
33.5   Milne to N Kulasekara, wide, lifter on the stumps, it is too high and rightly called a wide
33.4   Milne to Mathews, 1 run, short and on the hips, Mathews whips it behind square leg for a single
33.3   Milne to N Kulasekara, 1 run, fullish and just outside off, Kulasekara drives it to mid-off and scampers through for a quick single

33.2   Milne to N Kulasekara, no run, good length ball close to off, it was right in the corridor of uncertainty, the ball takes the outside edge as Kulasekara poked at it. Umpire Erasmus raised his finger, but Sri Lankan captain wanted it checked and he got it in his favour. There was no conclusive evidence to give that out

Umpire Erasmus raised his finger, but Mathews wanted him to check if Ronchi had taken it cleanly. They have sent it upstairs. Milne is fine with the no-ball. First few replays suggest that the ball bounced on the finger of the gloves and went in. The TV umpire thinks it hit the ground, so he overturns the on-field decision
33.1   Milne to N Kulasekara, no run, fuller and just outside off, Kulasekara drives it to short cover, picks out the fielder there
32.6   Vettori to N Kulasekara, 1 run, drags the length back, Kulasekara cuts it gently to sweeper cover
32.5   Vettori to N Kulasekara, no run, slower and close to off, Kulasekara blocks it towards cover
32.4   Vettori to N Kulasekara, no run, flighted on off, Kulasekara defends it back to the bowler
32.3   Vettori to N Kulasekara, no run, pushed through, Kulasekara plays it from around his pads to square leg. Had he missed, that would have been dead
32.2   Vettori to Mathews, 1 run, punched to sweeper cover
32.1   Vettori to Mathews, no run, slower and bit of turn, Mathews pokes at it with laden feet and is beaten
Nuwan Kulasekara, right handed bat, comes to the crease

31.6   Milne to J Mendis, out Caught by Ronchi!! Second wicket of the over and Milne troubling the Sri Lankan batsmen with his pace. It was short and aimed at the batsman, Mendis stays inside the line and tries to pull, gets top-edge that brushes his right shoulder on the way to Ronchi. Umpire Erasmus didn't think there was an edge, but he got it wrong as Mendis got a feather on that. Top review from McCullum, who took the word of Ronchi. J Mendis c Ronchi b Milne 4(4) [4s-1]
Milne to J Mendis, THATS OUT!! Caught!!

New Zealand have reviewed a caught behind appeal. Milne is fine with the front foot. First replays suggest that it came off the shoulder, but the Snicko suggests that he got a top-edge as well. The decision has been overturned. Mendis is gone!

31.5   Milne to J Mendis, FOUR, Mendis makes full use of the free-hit. Banged in halfway down the wicket, Mendis makes room and swats it high and towards deep mid-wicket, Anderson runs across, dives with one hand trying to catch the ball, but the ball eluded him
31.5   Milne to J Mendis, no ball, Milne oversteps by a long way and gives away a free-hit, fuller and homing in on off, Mendis shuffles across and knocks it towards mid-wicket

31.4   Milne to J Mendis, no run, peach! He brought his bat down after the ball had passed it. Stays round the wicket and slants it in, Mendis stays rooted to the crease and is late to bring his bat down, beaten off the toe-end
Jeevan Mendis, left handed bat, comes to the crease

31.3   Milne to D Karunaratne, out Bowled!! Cleaned up! The ploy to come round the wicket has worked for Milne. It is a dream delivery for any pacer, hitting the top of off-stump. Angled in from outside off, Karunaratne plays inside the line and looks to punch, is beaten for pace and the ball clatters into off-stump. The youngster pumps his fists in celebration. D Karunaratne b Milne 14(21)
Milne to D Karunaratne, THATS OUT!! Bowled!!
31.2   Milne to Mathews, 1 run, good early call for the single and they make it easily. Mathews bunts this to the right of Guptill at point and shouts for the single
31.1   Milne to D Karunaratne, 1 run, drifts it onto Karunaratne's pads, clipped away to deep square leg

Jamie with this now: " The asking rate is touching dangerous territory. Vettori operating into the breeze. The fans are loving this contest. Not a very verbal bunch, but most of the 17,228 gathered at Hagley Oval for this historic game are into the spirit."
30.6   Vettori to D Karunaratne, 1 run, tosses it up, Karunaratne fetches it from outside off and paddles it to deep backward square leg
30.5   Vettori to Mathews, 1 run, flatter and close to off, Mathews stays back and punches it to long-off
30.4   Vettori to Mathews, no run, pushes it to the left of Vettori this time, he does well to field it

30.3   Vettori to Mathews, FOUR, a rare loose delivery from Vettori, rank long hop on middle and leg, Mathews has all the time in the world to rock back and pull it over mid-wicket. That should make him feel good
30.2   Vettori to Mathews, no run, punched off the inside half to the right of the bowler, Vettori makes a tumbling stop
30.1   Vettori to Mathews, no run, loopy delivery on off, dead-batted down the pitch
29.6   Milne to D Karunaratne, no run, raps Karunaratne on the pads, but it was missing leg and height was also an issue. Karunaratne does not lay bat on the clip and wears it high on the pads
29.5   Milne to D Karunaratne, 2 runs, too straight, on the middle stump line, Karunaratne tucks it in front of square for a couple
29.4   Milne to D Karunaratne, no run, good length ball around off, Karunaratne defends it solidly to cover

29.3   Milne to Mathews, 1 run, direct hit and Mathews would have found himself short of the crease. He punches it to the right of backward point, the ball bounces nicely for Guptill to collect and have a shy at the bowler's end, he fails to hit the target though. Mathews was couple of yards short
29.2   Milne to D Karunaratne, 1 run, short on middle and leg, Karunaratne swivels and pulls it to deep backward square leg

Adam Milne [4.0-0-30-0] is back into the attack

A bit late, but never off the mark. Jamie on Thiri's dismissal: "That was a good ball to bowl Lahiru Thirimanne. Pitched it full, got it move away just to curl past the edge of Thirimanne's bat as he drove. New Zealand really need their quicks to deliver."

It was fraction quicker than the previous deliveries, looked to steer it even though there was a slip, ends up nicking it to the keeper. Massive wicket for New Zealand. Our man Jamie with this observation from the Hagley Oval: "Lahiru Thirimanne has carried Sri Lanka’s stiff chase to far with a fluent 43. Lots of nudges and dabs apart from one lovely cover drive off Adam Milne. That missed chance on 48 by Brendon McCullum at silly mid-on could hurt New Zealand. A good batting deck. Sri Lanka will need to keep wickets in tact for the back end of this innings."

It is time for a drinks break! Sri Lanka have started well, the opening pair of Dilshan and Thirimanne added 67 runs, the latter doing most of the scoring. Sangakkara has looked at ease. But they will know that they have a long way to go if they have to overhaul this target.

Here's James Alter with his analysis of the initial New Zealand bowling stint: "A bit of movement early on for Tim Southee, in particular, who has beaten Tillakaratne Dilshan. No really well-timed shots on view so far in Sri Lanka's reply. The full house is enjoying the game."

Welcome back for the reply. The 30 minutes has just flown by. Southee to start proceedings. Thirimanne and Dilshan are the batters. Here we go.

Phew that was some stint of commentary. 50 overs of high-octane action. My fingers are bleeding - just kidding of course - after all the pounding. Time to take a break and hand over commentary duties to the trusted Akshay. He will take you through the initial stages of the run chase. Do hang around. Don't stray too far.

Those supporting New Zealand, this stat might just make you even more optimistic. The Kiwis have not lost a game at home when they have scored above 300. They have won 14 and tied 1. So, can Sri Lanka end that run? Join us in a few minutes to find out...

The Sri Lankan bowlers lost the plot at the start of the innings when McCullum and Guptill went berserk. Nonetheless, Mathews opted for spin and Herath answered his call. The left-arm spinner bowled superbly and dragged things back along with Lakmal. But Kulasekara and Malinga had forgettable days, even though the latter came back strongly towards the end, he still went for above 8 per over. The fielding too was mediocre as there were a couple easy chances that were put down.

A couple of strikes from Jeevan Mendis put brakes on the scoring rate, but Anderson and Elliott added a crucial 65-run stand for the 5th wicket. The former went to register the third fifty of the innings. He smashed a 46-ball 75 to take his side past the 300-mark. His onslaught was such that, even the hard-hitting Ronchi played second fiddle to him.

Once the game started it was the Brendon McCullum show. The Kiwi skipper hammered the first two balls he faced to the boundary. He set the tone for the innings. Guptill took his time to get his bearings right, but once settled, he joined in the fun. The opening pair added 111 and set up a fine platform. Williamson came in after the fall of B-Mac and was dropped straightaway by Sanga. The in-form New Zealand batsman made the most of the chance as he too got to his fifty.

The first innings off the 2015 World Cup started amidst some drama. It was raining at the start of the day, but eased out for play to begin on time. However, rain returned once the national anthems were done and the players were about to take the field. It made sure that play started 5 minutes late.

What has happened here? Drama at the Hagley Oval. Sanga appeals for both a caught behind and a stumping. Ross Taylor is gone! Sanga fumbled with the initial take, but recovered in time to effect the stumping. Superb stuff from Sri Lanka, fighting back. Third umpire taking a lot of looks. The Zing bails are off even before Taylor could get his back foot back. Taylor overbalanced and missed the drive. The ball is in Sanga's right hand and he dislodges the bails. OUT is the signal and the crowd go silent, the Kiwi section that is.

2.4   N Kulasekara to Guptill, 1 run, a fumble from Jeevan Medis at mid-wicket, he went to his left and the ball slipped out of his grasp, they take a single
2.3   N Kulasekara to Guptill, no run, nips back in and cramps Guptill for room, the batsman punches it back to Kulasekara
Only a slip and a short cover now
2.2   N Kulasekara to Guptill, no run, punches to point
2.1   N Kulasekara to Guptill, no run, on a length and outside off, Guptill gets forward and defends to short cover

1.6   Malinga to Brendon McCullum, no run, well bowled and nearly did McCullum there. The slower delivery, dipped on the batsman and McCullum got his bat down as it came down as a full toss, if he hadn't got any wood, he would've been caught dead in front

1.5   Malinga to Brendon McCullum, FOUR, two balls and two boundaries for McCullum. Cracking shot again. It wasn't short, but McCullum rocked back and thumped it past the diving short cover. He surely doesn't need any sighters, this fella - Brendon McCullum! Malinga just blows some air and walks back to his mark

1.4   Malinga to Guptill, 3 runs, now Lakmal chases brilliantly and saves a run with a dive. It was clipped to his right at mid-on and the timing on the shot meant that he had to pull out the dive, did it well and prevented the boundary
1.3   Malinga to Guptill, no run, great fielding by Mathews at mid-off. It was punched to his left and he dived across to keep Guptill at his end. Saved a boundary
1.2   Malinga to Guptill, no run, short of length outside off, solidly defended to mid-off
1.1   Malinga to Guptill, 2 runs, Malinga starts with one down leg, Guptill tucks that to deep backward square leg, is off the mark with that couple
Lasith Malinga, right-arm fast, comes into the attack

Our man Jamie Alter from the ground says, "There's rain in the air, the temperature is 11 degrees. This could be a stop-start match. Chilly. Grey. Yet the crowd is cheerful, some Sri Lankan fans playing their trumpets."

0.6   N Kulasekara to Brendon McCullum, FOUR, an emphatic statement first up from McCullum! What a shot that is from the Kiwi skipper. It was overpitched outside off and McCullum just laced that up and over cover, no-one moved and the ball rocketed away. First boundary of the World Cup
Sangakkara is now coming up to McCullum. What will the Kiwi captain do? Expect anything!
0.5   N Kulasekara to Guptill, leg byes, 1 run, down leg, off the thigh pad and they take a leg bye
0.4   N Kulasekara to Guptill, no run, angling in to off, Guptill's bat face turned, but he defends to cover
0.3   N Kulasekara to Guptill, no run, nips back in but Guptill gets forward and defends solidly back to Kulasekara, Guptill showed the full face of the bat that time
Two slips in place for Kulasekara
0.3   N Kulasekara to Guptill, wide, the first runs of this World Cup! Way outside off and it's an easy call
The drizzle has picked up!
0.2   N Kulasekara to Guptill, no run, back of a length outside off and cuts back in, but not enough to hit off, so Guptill watchfully leaves that alone
0.1   N Kulasekara to Guptill, no run, the first ball of this World Cup and it's on a short of length outside off, doesn't move back in enough, so Guptill shoulders arms
Guptill and Brendon McCullum are at the crease. Guptill is on strike. N Kulasekara will open the attack

The Sri Lankans are in a huddle and they break out of it. The Kiwi openers are out in the middle and we have the countdown from 10 before we start off. There was a delay, but we now are ready to go. Kulasekara has the new ball and it will be Guptill to face off. Here we go then! Get it going. Let's get started.
11:03 Local Time, 22:03 GMT, 03:33 IST: The crowd clap and what do we have here. It's for an announcement that play will begin in five minutes. Great news then. The covers are coming off as well.

Blimey! What an anti-climax that is! The rain has made a reappearance! The pitch has been covered now. The umpires are under an umbrella. Crowd wrap themselves with blankets and take shelter. We are about to begin the game when the rain came. Sri Lanka's players went inside.

The Lankan anthem is done and it's now the turn of the BlackCaps. The Kiwi team wrap their arms around each other in a show of solidarity. The crowd are up on their feet and singing along. Brendon McCullum looks a bit grim though. Can't understand why. Hearty claps at the end of it. What an occasion and we are almost ready for the first ball.

The teams are out there for the national anthems. The premier of New Zealand, John Key is out there in attendance as well. Nice blustery, cold day at Christchurch. Lots of lovely couples seen on TV on Valentine's day. They have brought out blankets, pillows and what not to keep themselves warm. The Sri Lankan national anthem is first up and it's a beauty! Melodious and soulful.

Pitch Report: "It is overcast conditions. New Zealand know that they will swing the ball against Sri Lanka. There is a bit of grass. This is the Kakanui grass which has been used. There will be some movement early on. I think it is going to be a good, fast wicket," reckons Mark Richardson
Oh ho! As soon as the toss was done, the rain has started to arrive at the Hagley Oval. The main cover is on currently. Hopefully, it's just a minor blip and we should get the game started.
Teams:
New Zealand (Playing XI): Brendon McCullum(c), Martin Guptill, Kane Williamson, Ross Taylor, Grant Elliott, Corey Anderson, Luke Ronchi(w), Daniel Vettori, Tim Southee, Adam Milne, Trent Boult

Sri Lanka (Playing XI): Tillakaratne Dilshan, Lahiru Thirimanne, Kumar Sangakkara(w), Mahela Jayawardene, Angelo Mathews(c), Dimuth Karunaratne, Jeevan Mendis, Nuwan Kulasekara, Suranga Lakmal, Rangana Herath, Lasith Malinga
Sri Lanka have won the toss and have opted to field

Angelo Mathews: "It is nice to be here in New Zealand. All excited and ready to go. I will have a bowl as it is overcast and we are playing three seamers. The wicket looks fresh and we will look to exploit it. He (Dilshan) is alright and will be playing. Dinesh Chandimal, Thisara Perera, Dushmantha Chameera and Sachithra Senanayake are not playing. You will never get used to this kind of weather, but that is not an excuse, you will just have to go there and play positive cricket."

Brendon McCullum: "Yeah really excited to start the game at Christchurch. We would have bowled because of the overhead conditions. The wicket looks good. We have batted here in the past and have had some success. The guys are really excited getting into this World Cup and it is going to be a long campaign and it starts today. Some tough choices, Kyle Mills, Mitchell McClenaghan, Tom Latham and Nathan McCullum sit out today. It's a clean slate, we have had a fantastic preparation, we have played some outstanding cricket, had some personnel changes, but our gameplan remains the same. We have some confidence coming into the tournament, it is a clean slate. The tournament starts proper today, we will make sure that we execute our gameplan, if we do that, we will be hard to beat. But that doesn't guarantee you success either."
Great news coming in from the Hagley Oval - the covers are off!

Angelo Mathews reckons the past doesn't matter when he says this: "It is nice to have played a bit more cricket in New Zealand before the start of the World Cup, but from tomorrow onwards whoever plays the best cricket will go on to win."

Some quotes ahead of the game. Here is Brendon McCullum with this about how his side will be tough to beat if they play well - "You go out there and give your best and I'm confident that if we give our best then we'll be tough to beat."

Pre-match team news, Sri Lanka: One positive news for the Lankans ahead of the clash has been the declaration that Lasith Malinga is fit and will be available to play. It will be a battle between Karunaratne and Chandimal for the one middle-order spot. Jeevan Mendis and Rangana Herath are likely to be the two spinners.

After that declaration, it's back to business. Pre-match team news - New Zealand: All 15 are fit and available. McCullum knows what is his final XI is but hinted that he may make necessary adjustments depending on the weather. Elliot will bat at 5 with Anderson at 7. Vettori will be the main spinner. Milne is expected to get the nod over McClenaghan.

We don't want to brag or sound boastful here, but if you want the best coverage in terms of ball-by-ball content, then this is the place to come. We aspire and strive to give you the very best every ball, taking care not to miss a single piece of action. So since we have said it, you know where to head to each day of the World Cup. Needed to get that out of the closet!
Not great news coming in from our man, Jamie Alter, here's his tweet: "Its 11 degrees at Hagley Oval. Cold, grey. Drizzle in the air. Not looking good"
These two sides should know each other pretty well, having recently met in a seven match ODI series. So it will be interesting to see what sort of tactics we get to see in this match.

There is an over-reliance on Kumar Sangakkara, Mahela Jayawardene and Angelo Mathews to get them the runs with the bat. While the bowling without Lasith Malinga doesn't pose any threats with due respect to the likes of Kulasekara, Eranga and the others. One good news will be the return of Lasith Malinga. If Malinga is back amongst the wickets and the runs are put on the board by the batters, then we may yet see a different Sri Lankan team.

Sri Lanka on the other hand aren't going into the tournament as one of the favorites. The reason being their recent form hasn't been great. They were whitewashed by India away in a five match ODI series, also losing to New Zealand in the recently concluded ODI series. In between they defeated England at home 5-2 in a seven match series. But Sri Lanka at home are always a different proposition. So one shouldn't read too much into that series against England.

The bowling will be spearheaded by the swing sensations in Tim Southee and Trent Boult with able backup from the experienced Kyle Mills - who may find it difficult to get into the eleven, with the wily old fox Daniel Vettori weaving his magic. They are led by a brilliant strategist in Brendon McCullum and lots of experts including Martin Crowe think that this is their best chance to emerge triumphant after six semi-final appearances. Will they do it remains the big question though.

Just to let everyone know that they will take some stopping, they crushed South Africa by 134 runs in a warm-up game. The runs are flowing from the bats of Kane Williamson, Ross Taylor, Brendon McCullum and down the order they have the dangerous Luke Ronchi and Corey Anderson.

Why are New Zealand hot favorites? This is why. Their last three ODI series have gone like this - they beat Pakistan in the middle east 3-2 in a five match series. Then they thumped Sri Lanka 4-2 at home in a seven match series, before rounding off their World Cup preparations by defeating Pakistan 2-0 in a two match series at home.

Now onto the main action and that is involving New Zealand and Sri Lanka. New Zealand are the form team going into the World Cup and look in great shape at the moment. Their side is led by the inventive and swashbuckling Brendon McCullum and they possess enough firepower in their ranks to go all the way. They missed out in 92 when they looked set to win, but it won't be a surprise at all if they go the whole distance this time.

A massive crowd had turned up for the opening ceremony and it brought smiles on people's faces which was good to see. The residents of Christchurch needed this after all the heartache suffered in recent times.

It was a disaster that forever changed the lives of Christchurchians and slowly, but surely they are getting things back on track. So it was fitting in a way that the opening ceremony and the first game of the World Cup has been given to Christchurch. Gavin Larsen, the former New Zealand seamer put it perfectly at the opening ceremony when he remarked - "This is really important for Christchurch, the people really need something like this after the earthquake. It's just fantastic."

For the uninitiated, Christchurch was hit by a devastating earthquake in 2011. 22nd February 2011, a 6.3 magnitude aftershock of an earlier earthquake that occurred in September 2010 caused a disastrous disruption to Christchurch. There were nearly 200 fatalities and 10,000 injuries. Losses are estimated to be in the vicinity of 40 billion dollars.

So enough build-up given? I think so. Let's move on and shift our attention to today's game between New Zealand and Sri Lanka set to be played at the Hagley Oval in Christchurch. It's very important for me to mention about the resilience of Christchurchians. Resilience? Why you may ask?

Sachin Tendulkar. Jacques Kallis. Ricky Ponting. Muttiah Muralitharan. Kevin Pietersen. Some of the biggest stars to have played the game. Marquee names. Household names. Crowd pullers. Heroes. Role models. Unfortunately, we won't get to see them in action anymore as they have either retired/not picked. Their time is up. Time for new stars like Virat Kohli, Kane Williamson, David Warner and the rest to make a name for themselves. Who knows, the 2015 edition may throw up a new hero or an established star may make his career-defining performance.

As I said previously, there are so many wonderful past memories from World Cups gone by, that it will take me the entire day today and more to relive all of them. Just reminiscing about all the moments brings out pleasant and often unforgettable moments. Every player knows that for him to be recognised, he has to show off his skills to the entire world on the grandest stage of them all.

The World Cup is the stage for some of the greatest performers to strut their performances. And invariably, the champions pull off their best acts on the biggest stage of them all. From Clive Lloyd to IVA Richards to Kapil Dev to Wasim Akram to Aravinda de Silva to Shane Warne to Ricky Ponting to Glenn McGrath to MS Dhoni - the World Cup has seen them produce their defining work.

The tournament will be played over a duration of 44 days with the final scheduled to be taking place on the 29th of March at the 'G'. There will be many nerve-wracking, heart-stopping, exciting, thrilling - and all the other adjectives you can possible think of - memories that will be served up during the course of the tournament. Yes, there will be the comical, the utterly ridiculous, the controversial, the odd fight here and there thrown in as well. So in short - expect the unexpected and some more!

Hello and a warm welcome to wherever you are in any corner of the planet. The 2015 ICC World Cup is about to start off with a game between New Zealand and Sri Lanka. Before I go on about the respective sides' recent form, let me throw some more light on the 2015 tournament.

So many moments. I could go on and on and on. It's time for the biggest prize in world cricket - the carnival as they call it, to begin. Yes it's World Cup time again, folks! The 2015 World Cup is here and we are just warming ourselves up for what should be a celebration of the great game. It doesn't get any bigger than this!
MS Dhoni's surprise decision to promote himself in the final in 2011 - a move that was a masterstroke eventually
Zimbabwe in 83 and 99. Kenya in 96 and 2003. Ireland in 2011. The minnows come to the party!
Shane Warne being sent home in 2003 for a failed drug test after taking a banned diuretic
Sachin Tendulkar's 673 runs in 2003, yet nullified by Australia's dominance
That infamous and heart-breaking misunderstanding between Lance Klusener and Allan Donald which led to South Africa being labelled 'Chokers'
Shane Warne's magical spell when all seemed lost in the semi-final
Aravinda de Silva's classy hundred which marked his island country's greatest triumph
Wasim Akram's banana swingers that bemused a couple of Englishmen on a glorious night at the 'G'
Mike Gatting's ill-fated reverse sweep that cost the grand prize
07:47 Local Time, 19:47 GMT, 01:17 IST: Kapil Dev's outstanding athletic catch that turned the final and changed Indian cricket forever

Preview by Jamie Alter

New Zealand were in trouble against Zimbabwe. Zimbabwe beat Sri Lanka. Sri Lanka lost to South Africa. South Africa lost to New Zealand. Whatever significance has already been attached to these three results in Lincoln and Christchurch this week - Kyle Abbott termed it "amazing" to watch South Africa scrap to a narrow win, JP Duminy said they "weren't fazed" by defeat - is likely to evaporate come February 14 when the 2015 ICC World Cup begins at Hagley Park. The nature of the warm-up game is such that teams tend not to take them too seriously, with the option of fielding all 15 players. But history has shown us that you really cannot read too much into them. In a 2007 World Cup warm-up, India bowled out West Indies for 85 and we all know how that tournament turned out for them.

Game one of the World Cup features the hosts New Zealand, riding a high over the last year and coming off a 134-run hammering of South Africa at the very venue for Saturday, the scenic Hagley Oval, facing Sri Lanka - finalists in the last two World Cups. Two teams with good World Cup records, and who know each other pretty well. Sri Lanka have been stationed in the country for about seven weeks, and would have a good sense of the conditions. New Zealand, skippered by Brendon McCullum, are being talked up as title contenders after their best-ever Test year and with ODI series wins over India, Pakistan and Sri Lanka.

On Friday, a day before the World Cup opener in Christchurch, McCullum was asked once again about the added pressure of captaining one of the favourites, who are in excellent form, in front of the home fans. This is a massive game not only for the home team but for the host city, which remains in parts devastated from the aftermath of the tragic 2011 earthquakes. Whoever you ask, the theme of Christchurch's sporting fans needing reason to cheer has been resonant.

"I've got a job to do and its all-encompassing in terms of captaincy, opening the batting and trying to execute the strategies on the field. Is there extra pressure? I guess it is there on everyone," he said. "Just because the nature of it being a World Cup, I'm excited about it and I have high ambitions as to what I want to achieve. Whether you achieve them or not is another thing, but I go in feeling reasonably confident and secure in the fact that I'm surrounded by guys who I trust and believe in."

Belief. It's a word that has in a sense epitomised New Zealand's surge as a team over in the year leading up to the World Cup. Against India, a team that has regularly bossed them in ODIs in recent years, they won 4-0 last January. Then a Test series win in the West Indies, a 2-0 ODI loss at home to South Africa, before a come-from-behind Test draw against Pakistan in the UAE. In the subsequent ODIs, New Zealand won 3-2. Sri Lanka landed in the country and were beaten in the Tests and ODIs, then Pakistan handed a 2-0 ODI series loss. How do you not believe that this is a team who believes in itself?

"When you go into a tournament as underdogs, dark horses or favourites, it is all irrelevant once the games start," reckoned McCullum. "It's great because it drums up energy and anticipation and expectation, but once the game actually starts it is back to the contest in its purest form - which is bat and ball and someone wins and someone loses. So that is the mentality we've got and we know what works for us. That is all we can focus, not on how some people have an expectation from us and how some people are writing us off. It is irrelevant from our point of view. We know what we need to do to succeed and if someone else is good enough to beat us, then so be it."

Sri Lanka are also riding on belief, their captain Angelo Mathews insisted while he spoke of what the team has learnt from their time in the country. "It is nice to have played a bit more cricket in New Zealand before the start of the World Cup, but from tomorrow onwards whoever plays the best cricket will go on to win," he said. "I think we have a slight advantage. We got used to the conditions, we have a fair idea of what the wickets are like, but we've got to be aggressive and play good cricket to win against New Zealand. They are on a roll, they've been winning plenty of games in the recent past, so we need to back our strengths and be positive."

Sri Lanka have not zeroed in on their playing XI for Saturday's match, but Mathews confirmed that Lasith Malinga would play. His addition gives the team its bowling spearhead, a sling-arm fast bowler with 271 ODI wickets and the experience of two World Cups, during which he left an impression on both occasions. The significance of Malinga's return - he has taken 29 wickets against New Zealand in 21 ODIs - was not lost on McCullum.

"He's a world-class bowler who makes a significant difference to their bowling line-up," he said. "Predominantly at the back end of the game. He's a phenomenal death bowler, a factor which we have to overcome if we're going to succeed in this game. If we can head into those final overs with a nice platform, and if we've ticked off some of our key ingredients along the way, then hopefully we can put him under a little bit of pressure. Certainly Sri Lanka is a stronger team for Lasith Malinga's involvement."

If the conditions at Hagley Park over the two warm-up matches here this week are any indication, the surface will encourage batting and bowling. On Monday, Sri Lanka got to 279 for 7 in 44.4 overs and asked tough questions of South Africa who stumbled to a D/L revised target of 188 with three balls and five wickets remaining. Sri Lanka's innings contained a cut-and-pull-fuelled century off 82 balls by Tillakaratne Dilshan. On Wednesday, New Zealand racked up 331 for 8 in 50 overs and then bowled out South Africa for 197 in 44.2, with Boult and Tim Southee's early strikes effectively ending the match as a contest before Duminy and Vernon Philander produced gritty fifties.

Having played two one-day matches here on tour - an ODI in January and Monday's warm-up against South Africa - Mathews knew the nature of the surface. "It depends on the weather, but the wicket looks really good. There will be a lot of runs," he said. "If it is a good wicket, we will try and bat first. We've got the bowlers to stop the opposition and if we have to bowl first, we've got the experience in our batting [to chase]. So it doesn't really matter for us. As long as we play good cricket, our brand of cricket, we will be able to win."

McCullum echoed Mathews' views. "[The pitch] looks good, looks like it's got a bit of bounce and should be an even cricket wicket," he said. "That's what you want in a World Cup, a pitch that has a bit for both parties. We're going to have an even surface on which the team that plays the best cricket will come out on top. It's a good wicket that's been prepared."
Teams:

Sri Lanka (From): Tillakaratne Dilshan, Lahiru Thirimanne, Kumar Sangakkara(w), Mahela Jayawardene, Angelo Mathews(c), Dinesh Chandimal, Thisara Perera, Jeevan Mendis, Nuwan Kulasekara, Rangana Herath, Lasith Malinga, Sachithra Senanayake, Suranga Lakmal, Dimuth Karunaratne, Dushmantha Chameera

New Zealand (From): Brendon McCullum(c), Martin Guptill, Kane Williamson, Ross Taylor, Grant Elliott, Corey Anderson, Luke Ronchi(w), Daniel Vettori, Tim Southee, Adam Milne, Trent Boult, Mitchell McClenaghan, Kyle Mills, Nathan McCullum, Tom Latham
